item.title: A simple process to start exploratory data analysis
item.author: rachit.kinger@gmail.com (rachit kinger)
item.description: At work I often find myself with a new dataset. It is an exciting feeling to have successfully downloaded a large, recent dataset that is also clean. Often times I find these datasets need to be extracted from one of the platforms that we use at work. But without getting into how these datasets are extracted I will share some tips on how I approach the datasets in a way that helps me quickly derive some initial insights.

item.title: Sorting the bars of a bar chart in increasing or decreasing order
item.author: rachit.kinger@gmail.com (rachit kinger)
item.description: Here is a simple trick to make the bars in a bar chart appear in order of their height - highest to lowest (or lowest to highest). Letâ€™s say we want to plot the number of cars of each class that we have in the mpg dataset. library(dplyr) library(ggplot2) mpg %>% ggplot() + geom_bar(aes(x = class)) If you look at class(mpg$class) you will see that it is: ## [1] "character" However, ggplot converts it into factor and if you convert it into factor you will notice that the orders in which the bars appear in the bar chart above is the same order in which the list has recorded the levels of the variable class.

item.title: About
item.author: rachit.kinger@gmail.com (rachit kinger)
item.description: My name is Rachit Kinger. I blog about things in data science, digital inequality and linux that I found difficult to understand or learn. Professionally, I am head of data and analytics at a regional media company in the UK called Johnston Press. We publish close to 200 news sites that cover mainly small towns and villages in the UK. Some of our big titles include The Scotsman, The Yorkshire Post, inews (which won the British Media Awards for the website of the year - in the same year that Guardian launched its new website!
